title: How to Color Titanium

steps.headline: Coat the titanium in phosphoric acid (cola will do).
steps.description: This is easily done by filling a paint roller's pan (or a shallow tub) with cola, then dipping the titanium into the pan.

steps.headline: Attach a wire to the titanium with a clip, then attach a battery (or multiple batteries) to the wire.
Attach another wire to the paint brush, then attach the same batteries to this wire.
steps.description: It does not matter if the batteries' positive or negative terminals is attached to the titanium or brush, as long as current flows in one direction.

steps.headline: Fill a jar with cola, then dip the paint brush to coat it in cola.
Experiment with various voltages to achieve different colors:

tyn: Titanium in any form. Titanium sheets cost approximately $33 US a square foot.
Numerous 9 volt batteries, or an AC to DC adapter.
Wire or clips to connect batteries to the brush.
text:
Coat the titanium in phosphoric acid (cola will do). This is easily done by filling a paint roller's pan (or a shallow tub) with cola, then dipping the titanium into the pan. Attach a wire to the titanium with a clip, then attach a battery (or multiple batteries) to the wire. Attach another wire to the paint brush, then attach the same batteries to this wire. It does not matter if the batteries' positive or negative terminals is attached to the titanium or brush, as long as current flows in one direction. Fill a jar with cola, then dip the paint brush to coat it in cola. Experiment with various voltages to achieve different colors: {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/08\/Color_titanium_color_chart1.jpg\/460px-Color_titanium_color_chart1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/08\/Color_titanium_color_chart1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":68,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":112.48,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader

sentences: Coat the titanium in phosphoric acid (cola will do).
This is easily done by filling a paint roller's pan (or a shallow tub) with cola, then dipping the titanium into the pan.
Attach a wire to the titanium with a clip, then attach a battery (or multiple batteries) to the wire.
Attach another wire to the paint brush, then attach the same batteries to this wire.
It does not matter if the batteries' positive or negative terminals is attached to the titanium or brush, as long as current flows in one direction.
Fill a jar with cola, then dip the paint brush to coat it in cola.
